verses.text: All the tax collectors and sinners were coming near to Jesus to listen to Him.
verses.comment: Jesus attracts those regarded as outsiders, highlighting God's openness to all who seek him.

verses.text: The Pharisees and the scribes began to grumble, saying, 'This man welcomes sinners and eats with them.'
verses.comment: The religious leaders object to Jesus' fellowship with sinners, showing a contrast between human judgment and divine mercy.

verses.text: So He told them this parable:
verses.comment: Jesus often teaches in parables to reveal deep spiritual truths to those open to faith.

verses.text: 'Which one of you, if you has a hundred sheep and loses one of them, does not leave the ninety-nine in the open country, and go after the one that is lost until he finds it?'
verses.comment: This verse uses the imagery of a shepherd, linking Jesus with the God of Israel in the Old Testament who seeks His lost people.

verses.text: When he finds it, he joyfully lifts it up on his shoulders.
verses.comment: The shepherd's joy and action shows God’s tender care, physically carrying the lost; a model for spiritual leaders.

verses.text: And when he comes home, he calls together his friends and neighbors, saying to them, 'Rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep that was lost!'
verses.comment: God’s joy is shared with His community, signifying both personal and communal rejoicing over every conversion.

verses.text: I tell you, there will be more rejoicing in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous persons who have no need of repentance.
verses.comment: Repentance is deeply valued in God’s eyes. Heaven’s joy reflects the importance of turning away from sin.

verses.text: 'Or what woman, having ten silver coins, if she loses one coin, does not light a lamp, sweep the house, and search carefully until she finds it?'
verses.comment: The coin parable continues, now with a woman, showing God’s searching love is thorough and meticulous, like the care of a household.

verses.text: When she has found it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, 'Rejoice with me, for I have found the coin that I lost!'
verses.comment: Personal loss restored leads to community celebration, again reflecting the unity of God’s people in joy.

verses.text: Similarly, I tell you, there is joy in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner who repents.
verses.comment: This emphasizes the spiritual significance of repentance and the shared joy among God’s heavenly council.

verses.text: Then He said, 'A certain man had two sons.'
verses.comment: Jesus introduces the Parable of the Prodigal Son, a narrative rich in spiritual meaning about forgiveness and restoration.

verses.text: The younger of them said to his father, 'Father, give me the share of the inheritance that belongs to me.' So he divided his wealth between them.
verses.comment: The son’s request would be shocking, showing a break from family unity, echoing how sin can separate us from God’s household.

verses.text: Not many days later, the younger son gathered all he had, traveled to a distant country, and squandered his property in reckless living.
verses.comment: Sin leads to self-imposed exile and waste. The 'distant country' symbolizes separation from God’s grace.

verses.text: When he had spent everything, a severe famine hit that country, and he began to be in need.
verses.comment: Hardship often reveals our need for God, just as famine did for Israel in the Old Testament.

verses.text: So he went and hired himself out to a citizen of that country, who sent him into his fields to feed pigs.
verses.comment: Tending pigs was especially shameful for Jews, underlining the younger son's spiritual destitution.

verses.text: He longed to fill his stomach with the pods the pigs were eating, but no one gave him anything.
verses.comment: True spiritual hunger and emptiness comes from separation from the Father—a type of spiritual famine.

verses.text: But when he came to his senses, he said, 'How many of my father’s hired servants have more than enough bread, but I am dying here with hunger!'
verses.comment: The turning point begins with recognition and contrition, like repentance—central to entering back into God’s family.

verses.text: 'I will get up and go to my father, and I will say to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you.’'
verses.comment: Confession of sin 'against heaven' models true repentance and humility.

verses.text: 'I am no longer worthy to be called your son; make me like one of your hired servants.'
verses.comment: The son forsakes status, ready to be a servant—mirroring Christian humility and the process of restoration.

verses.text: So he got up and went to his father. But while he was still far off, his father saw him and was filled with compassion; he ran to his son, embraced him, and kissed him.
verses.comment: The father’s action shows God’s readiness to restore those who return even before they fully arrive. Running to meet his son reveals divine initiative in reconciliation.

verses.text: The son said to him, 'Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you; I am no longer worthy to be called your son.'
verses.comment: Confession leads the way to forgiveness—demonstrating that reconciliation begins with humility.

verses.text: But the father said to his servants, 'Quick! Bring out the best robe and put it on him. Put a ring on his hand and sandals on his feet.'
verses.comment: The gifts—robe, ring, sandals—are marks of full restoration to sonship, not mere servitude, prefiguring God’s grace given through spiritual means.

verses.text: 'Bring the fattened calf and kill it. Let us celebrate and feast!'
verses.comment: The feast signifies celebration, echoing communal celebrations in the Old Testament and pointing to the Heavenly banquet.

verses.text: 'For this son of mine was dead and is alive again! He was lost and is found!' And they began to celebrate.
verses.comment: The son’s restoration from death to life prefigures spiritual rebirth—a key theme of salvation.

verses.text: Now the elder son was in the field. When he came near the house, he heard music and dancing.
verses.comment: The elder son is introduced, representing those who remain in the household but misunderstand grace.

verses.text: So he called one of the servants and asked what these things meant.
verses.comment: The elder son’s confusion points to the mystery of God’s forgiveness and the difficulty some have accepting its breadth.

verses.text: 'Your brother has come,' he replied, 'and your father has killed the fattened calf because he has received him back safe and sound.'
verses.comment: The safe return is cause for rejoicing, and restoration is described in familial and physical wholeness.

verses.text: But he became angry and would not go in. So his father came out and pleaded with him.
verses.comment: The father’s initiative toward both sons shows the inclusiveness of divine mercy, even for the righteous who misunderstand grace.

verses.text: He answered his father, 'Look, all these years I’ve served you and never disobeyed your orders, yet you never gave me even a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends.'
verses.comment: The elder son’s protest is rooted in legalism, missing the essence of relationship—echoing themes of grace over works.

verses.text: But when this son of yours who has squandered your property with prostitutes returns, you kill the fattened calf for him!'
verses.comment: The elder son distances himself from his brother, lacking the compassionate love the father displays.

verses.text: 'My son,' the father said, 'you are always with me, and all that is mine is yours.'
verses.comment: The father’s assurance points to the constant availability of God’s riches for the faithful.

verses.text: 'But it was right to celebrate and be glad, for this brother of yours was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.'
verses.comment: Joy in the recovery of the lost reveals God’s heart: restoration, not condemnation. The structure of the parable hints at the necessity of repentance and full integration into the family, which prefigures entry into the fullness of God’s People.
